lift.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to move something or someone upwards into the air
lift.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Sophie lifted the phone before the second ring.
He lifted the lid on the pot of soup.
The lumber was lifted by crane and dropped into the truck.
They lifted Andrew onto the bed.
lift somebody/something onto/into/out of etc something
The driver was lifted from the wreck.
lift.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to move part of your body up to a higher position
lift.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: He heard a scream and the hairs on the back of his neck began to lift.
She lifted her hand to knock on the door once again.
Pam lifted her shoulders in a little shrug.
She lifted her head to gaze at him.
lift.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to remove a rule or a law that says that something is not allowed
lift.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: The government plans to lift its ban on cigar imports.
lift.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to take people or things to or from a place by aircraft
lift.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: More troops are being lifted into the area as the fighting spreads.
lift.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: if cloud or mist lifts, it disappears
lift.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: if feelings of sadness lift, they disappear
lift.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: Jan’s depression seemed to be lifting at last.
lift.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to take words, ideas etc from someone else’s work and use them in your work, without stating where they came from and as if they were your own words etc
lift.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: The words were lifted from an article in a medical journal.
lift.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: They had lifted dozens of CDs from the store.
lift.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: if you lift your voice, you speak, shout, or sing more loudly
lift.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: to make prices, profit etc increase
lift.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: The U.S. may use tax cuts to lift the economy.
lift.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: to dig up vegetables that grow under the ground
lift.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: lift (up)
to move something or someone upwards to a higher position, especially something heavy, either by using your hands or a machine
You shouldn’t lift anything heavy if you have a bad back.
She lifted the lid from a huge pot and took a sniff.
They lifted me onto a stretcher and took me to the ambulance.
He lifted the girl up onto his knee.
They used a crane to lift the carriages back onto the rails.
The massive bull lifted him bodily into the air and shook him repeatedly.
to lift something to a higher position for a short time before lowering it again. Raise is more formal than lift
The bridge can be raised to allow ships to pass under it.
‘Cheers, everyone!’ said Larry, raising his glass.
pick up
to lift something up from the ground, from a table etc, especially something small or light
She picked up her bag and left the room.
Tom picked the papers up off the floor.
Why don’t you just pick up the phone and call him?
Maurin picked up the gun and put it in his pocket.
The lioness picked her cub up by its neck.
There are papers all over the floor – could you pick them up and put them away?
The little girl’s mother laughed and bent down to pick her up.
The vacuum cleaner won’t pick this stuff up.
scoop up
to lift someone or something quickly from the ground, from a table etc, using your hand or arm
She bent down and scooped up the little dog.
hoist
to lift up something which is heavy and difficult to carry
Joe picked up the sack and hoisted it onto the truck.
The crowd hoisted him onto their shoulders and carried him triumphantly down the main street.
elevate
to lift something to a higher position and keep it there
The doctor advised me to rest and elevate my ankle.
put your hand up
to lift your arm into the air, for example because you want to speak in a class or when voting
Put your hand up if you know the answer.
lift.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a machine that you can ride in, that moves up and down between the floors in a tall building
lift.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: They took the lift down to the bar.
It’s on the 3rd floor. Let’s use the lift.
lift.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: if you give someone a lift, you take them somewhere in your car
lift.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: Do you want a lift into town?
John gave me a lift home.
He very kindly offered me a lift.
lift.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: a movement in which something is lifted or raised up
lift.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: She does sit-ups and leg lifts every morning.
lift.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: the pressure of air that keeps something such as an aircraft up in the air or lifts it higher
lift.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to make prices, profits etc rise
lift.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Improving international demand lifted product prices.
The interim dividend to shareholders has been lifted from 2.7p to 3.02p.
lift.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to remove a law or rule
lift.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: After the exchange controls were lifted, Swedes rushed to invest abroad.
the decision to lift economic sanctions against the country
